Awesome game, abysmal company. Will update rating when I received my KS stuff from years ago.

The box content is a wonderful illusion: you open the box, glance through the cards with their beautiful art, look at the huge number of mini assembly kits and marvel at their detail, look at the big ass cards (settlement and tech) and your mind starts running through all sorts of post post post end of a tainted, fairy-like world full of mysteries / legacies.
Hold on to those precious moments - that will be your highlight of the KDM experience. Write notes, start your secondary world creation based on that material.
The actual play experience will crush these moments and make you regret you ever played it (and mind the damage to your wallet too).
You're better off gathering as much lore as you can and use the material in an RPG campaign. I guarantee that the experience at the table will be more enjoyable. On that note I have nothing against crapsack worlds / theme / settings. What kills the user experience at the table here is the randomness (especially in connection to the lethality), the grind and the clunky combat system / equipment pr0n.
I guess the designer wanted to "subvert expectations", which can never, never go wrong, right?
It's a shame, really. The design of the minis is superlatively good but the rest is profoundly disappointing.

The poster boy for all the issues with the Kickstarter process of game publishing. This game is tedious with too much to account for.

The game experience is a long drawn out train wreck. Great to watch as entertainment, horribly troubling to experience.

Also, the art is disgusting, disturbing, and pervy. Like a bad reality show where the writers and actors have stopped caring and only seek your attention through shock and aggravation.

Overpriced (400+ CAD) with component creep. This game also serves as promotion for miniatures that have no gameplay purpose.

Barely qualifies as a game.
Let's make something absolutely clear: when a game instructs me to draw a card, which tells me to roll a die and look up a reference table that then claims I have achieved or failed something, *I* have not achieved/failed anything. I haven't even participated.

You do not play Kingdom Death: Monster.
You are merely the flesh engine moving the components as the game plays itself.
Decisions don't matter. Players don't matter. Free will is an illusion.
Only the capricious will of dice and shuffled cards.

It doesn't even have the grace keep my torment short.
I have no agency and I must scream.

I dig the aesthetic vibe though!

It barely qualifies as a game. This was more of a social experiment to see how much wool could be pulled over the eyes. Played this several times because friends got so excited for it to come in. An extra .5 because someone on the team gave a darn for 5 minutes and wrote some interesting ai mechanics. I hope a better game/game company down the line takes some inspiration from them.

Kickstarter. Cooperative horror game for 1-4 players. Complex rules and a steep learning curve. I suspect I will only play this solo. If I ever find someone willing to play with me, I will almost certainly become the "Alpha Player" and dictate all actions in the game. That's frustrating both for me and the others. The game is hard. Really hard. Lots of random cards drawn and lots of dice rolled. Too much is random. And the outcome is quite often instant death for a character, without anything you can do about it. Extremely frustrating. It seems almost impossible to complete the game. And even if some extreme luck should bring victory in the final showdown it's gonna take hundreds of hours to get there. It'll never happen. It has nice miniatures but why must I glue them together myself? I'm not very skilled as a miniature builder and the results are "acceptable" at best. And why the juvenile sexist design? So I don't like this game at all. Normally I don't consider price a factor when I rate my games. But when a game costs this much it has to be considered. It's the most expensive game I've ever bought. I'm so sorry, but put it all together and it's the worst thing I have in my collection. Rating it as 1.

Edit: I've added a few house rules to remove some of the worst frustrations with this game. It's playable now. But it still happens that you send four characters on a hunt. After several hours of fighting two of them return carrying some "Love Juice" they've recovered - only to roll a "1" on the intimacy table, instantly killing them both. Where's the strategy in this? Is it fun with a game that works this way? Way too random for me! Rating stays at 2, and will probably never rise any higher.

Edit: Built all the monsters now. They're not that many considering that the box costs $400. I also tried playing it again this weekend. Just to be sure. And I still think it's crap. Apart from what I've already said I should add that drawing a card, which tells me to roll on a table, which tells me to draw another card, roll on another table, draw again, roll again, etc, until finally some (probably lethal) effect ends the cicle, is kind of boring. It isn't actually playing a game. It's just following instructions. I was lucky with the cards and dice this time, but I almost set the score back to 1 anyway.

Update march 2023: Sold online for SEK 2600.

TIme to setup and teardown are massive. The amount of upkeep during a campaign is just as big.

The gameplay itself, follows along the same line. Everything is designed to take longer than it needs to. Yes the fights against monsters are epic, but once you fight the same monster over and over you wish they were shorter.

This is the kind of game that makes me think it would work well as a computer game, by having all the annoying stuff automated. But without that it's simply too cumbersome to play.

Game is repetitive, the rules are clunky, and the settlement phase is a huge slog. The art is pretty cool and the overall look of the game is great, but this doesn't redeem the overcomplicated gameplay.

The game feels like two different games smashed together. One game is a settlement and campaign game, where you have to make choices between short term and long term outcomes. The other game feels like a one shot dungeon crawl. Combined together and the game doesn't feel like an uphill battle, which I would be fine with. I have played enough games likes this and found paths to victory. Even losing those kinds of games can be fun because you can see what you did wrong or if one bad luck did it. Kingdom Death: Monster feels like a downhill slide where you hope random chance decides to somehow move you uphill. You will lose through no fault of your own and even worse, you will lose because you are doing too well.

Played at a convention. This game is terrible. I cannot understand how anyone justifies it as a quality game. So many better campaign games out there.

Great things about the game: beautiful components, clear Berserk manga inspiration art style and dynamic enemies that feel like they are "thinking", which adds tons of replay value. The gear grid system and synergy squares really work well for the game. The feeling of helplessness like you're trapped in a bizarre post-Eclipse world of Berserk, building a settlement out of the weird alien landscape and monsters. Essentially, Monster Hunter meets Berserk.

The bad: This game either wasn't playtested enough or the designers just don't give a shit about math. I can tell when someone tried to make the math of their game work despite not being very good at it and when they just slapped whatever together and hoped it would work as long as things had numbers relative to each other. KD:M is a clear example of the latter as none of the probabilities seem to have been worked out ahead of time to ensure the difficulty was as-intended. Most things in this game have you rolling on a table (a bit outdated but okay, I can work with this). However, several tables are simply broken, skipping numbers like this:
1-3
4-6
8-9
10
Where is 7? This happens repeatedly since the designers want to have no more than 4 table rows on most of them and shoe-horn 10 by itself most of the time. The dice you roll are inconsistent. Sometimes it's 1d10, sometimes 2d10 additive, sometimes d%(aka d100) and sometimes d5?? Not only is this jarring but rarely do they have you "check" any of your skills. These rolls are just totally out-of-your-control randomness. I get that maybe they were going for a "the universe is uncaring" feel but the rest of the game brings that oppressively, so I'm not sure why you'd have players rolling on broken inconsistent tables which are independent of player stats. On top of this, half the time you roll on a table just to roll on another table, which usually means the only "good" outcome is roll a 10 to roll a 10 on another table, which is a 1/100 chance. Same for the worst outcomes. Meaning most of the time you end up "taking 1 damage" or "getting a -1 token" to some stat or whatever the generics are. Essentially the events in the book all feel like they're trying to grief players rather than challenge them. There are way too many random event rolls in this game. Just as an example, coming back to town where you are usually safe, there's a random event deck you draw from and then on one card you can draw there's a random table you must roll. Within that table there is ANOTHER random table you roll. You can also spend precious endeavor points (1 per player) to roll on tables, which usually have a 30% chance to screw you, 30% chance to do nothing, 30% chance to do nothing of note, and a 10% chance to do something insanely good for no reason.

Most of the moral choices in the game come down to literally "save baby or eat baby" style that modern video games bring. I could go on and on about how bad the math is and how "sacky" the game feels with the monster traps and imperviousness. It seems the designers thought the only way monsters could live after a single upgrade session from players is to make them nullify half the players' attacks that actually hit; the other half always missing due to having a to-hit system followed by ANOTHER to-hit system a la Warhammer 40k. But this isn't a wargame and we aren't rolling buckets of dice. You're lucky to roll 3 attack dice early game for instance. Do the math:
At +1 accuracy and a target 7 weapon, you roll at a target 6. Of 2 dice, 1 will make it (50% chance each die). Of that 1 die, you now roll your +1 strength against a monster's 9 toughness, with a weapon strength of 2. Adding Str + weapon = 3, so you get +3 to your roll which averages at 6, so 9. Just barely a hit. So in other words, you have to do exactly the average on two different rolls which are subsets of each other. That means you need 4 dice to hit once. If one of those hit locations is First Strike, Impervious or a Trap, you're likely screwed. Don't get me wrong. I love the difficulty in the game as it provides a tactical challenge. But it relies way too much on griefing players who actually succeeded against all odds to make any difference.

On top of this, rolling a natural 10 and critting some areas requires then rolling another nat 10 to make the monster instantly die? So that's the probability that:
-The player hit with at least one die
-Then drew that hit location card out of 30 others
-Then rolled a nat 10
-Then rolled another nat 10
Why even have this effect when this is the least likely thing to happen ever? You're talking about 1/2 * 1/30 * 1/10 * 1/10 = 1/6000! You'd have to fight that thing 6000 times for it to happen, give or take since Hit Location decks increase the chances of seeing it as you go through but traps decrease the chances.

Overall, FIX YOUR FUCKING MATH and you'll become an easy recommend from me. If you have a group willing to just ignore most of the non-effort put into the rolling and tables, then it can be an absolute blast. None of the "horror" theme is really evoked there. Tough decisions is what makes a horror theme. Randomness is the literal opposite of a decision. It's an intriguing game with a lot of potential and while not really worth my money, you should at least play with a friend if they offer.

Update Sept 2019: Pretty sure the Strength +1 token depicts a man raping a woman. And is labelled "Strength". I think I might puke my entire skeleton. The game is already pretty shitty to women and I managed to exclude from my earlier comments that it disrespectfully reduces humanity to their ability to reproduce for the civ-management section of the game, which is just a ridiculous heterosexual fantasy. In our games, we just designate two types of women (there aren't any men in our play group) and the two different women types (Type A and Type B) suffice just like the "Gender" marker in the game for civ management. With humanity being sprung up from the earth in-lore, they should've ditched sexuality anyway as a concept. Humanity more resembles thinking plants in KDM so I don't see why there needs to be a strict gender binary role that mimics our *actual* horrorshow of a society today and forces you to be complicit in that by dehumanizing those bodies into reproductive factories.

I'm not sure why I ever rated this a 6 given that RAW, the game is a broken unplayable mess and extremely annoying. I have to throw my rating down the toilet to a 2 especially given that every time I consider playing, even with a group that is fine ignoring some rolls/draws to keep the fun going, there's always some part of the game that tells me I'm not welcome as a woman. Instead, the game considers women only heterosexual and just meatbags for reproduction, violation, and tragedy. This differs from the general violation that exists to all genders in the game already and is extra and on top of that.

Update Nov 2019: I started to suspect KDM is only enjoyed by people for the miniatures and paining, rarely for the gameplay so I dug into the community resources a bit only to find that most of my search results were how-tos on mini assembly/painting. Even when I specifically used terms like "kingdom death primer" it would link to paint primer tutorials or "kingdom death beginner guide" it would link to beginner painter guides overwhelmingly. I have a lot of disdain for the fact that what amounts to a pretty unfinished broken game with significant problems is being standarded above an 8 by a majority minis-enthusiast community. There's nothing wrong with liking miniatures, I just wish games could be rated based on their play experiences rather than colored by plastic pushing. This update was from a 7 (good but heavily flawed) to a 2 after I actually bought the game and experienced how indefensibly broken it is.
Lots of pieces. At one point, it just feels like a shock- horror movie. The artwork is good...but bits of obscenity turn me off; I can't play with certain people (my kids).

This game involved the most childish F-you ending I've ever encountered in a campaign and I'm so irritated that I simply can't recommend this game to anyone, ever, period.

Did you hate the ending of Game of Thrones? Well, I hope you're looking forward to feeling the same way when this game ends. This is a game for people who hate joy and/or are masochists. Or who like spending exorbitant amounts of money only to be disappointed (rich masochists?).

And we can all just agree that a lot of the art is sexist, pretty much towards both genres. I've said it, let's move on.

While the time my friends and I had together with this game was great and creating your own minis was delightful, the game is too hard. Not in a fun way, in a F-you sort of way. You'll never figure it out on your first play-through, so be prepared to have a bad time and not finish your first campaign, because you realize you need to look everything up online to get anywhere. Then, prepare for the game to screw you over at every turn, regardless of successful die roles. It's not fair, like in DnD. No, you can still roll the equivalent of a Nat20 in this game and get boned. The game's default setting is "unfair" but not in a way like Dark Souls that's just hard. Even a victory feels like a failure but these failures don't follow any logic. If they did, I could accept it, but they don't make any sense whatsoever.

The pacing is terrible. Everything is too hard in the beginning, followed by a bunch of boring grinds of the same lion and antelope fights that only get harder but not more interesting, so the hunts get exhausting and longer as the game goes. While the events in the game can be fun and interesting, you need to have some sense of some reward coming that never really comes.

And then we get to the ending (spoilers here on out)

The final boss is with someone called The Watcher. The idea is that the Watcher is like one of those angler fish, with the lantern being its lure. So the lanterns where you build your civilization are part of The Watcher, who awakens every once in a while and devours the civilization that is built there. Pretty cool, right? So we fight The Watcher and we won! Hell yes, but then we get the ending text which says, essentially, that no matter what you do, you don't have light anymore so you die. You can keep playing if you like, but you will die eventually.

That's the most childish "lol F you" ending to a game I've ever played.

If it had been left open, like "you must go forward in darkness... will your civilization survive?", I'd have been completely satisfied. After our victory, we were all amped up to celebrate, but after reading that, it sucked the wind from our sails. It essentially told us that we weren't allowed to imagine what happens next, but rather, that whatever we did, we're screwed. Truly, it felt like the ending of Game of Thrones.

Ultimately, there was a lot of fun to be had in the game, but all of it was rendered null by the ending. Poots is a creative guy but his storytelling is childish and simply bad.

Maybe I'll do a DnD mod for this game and make this good...

Very disappointing, but, admittedly, I fell for the roof-shattering hype this game emits. I should have also considered the fact that most of the energy and advertising is directed toward miniatures not gameplay. Funnily enough, when asking friends what their favorite mechanic of the game is, no one can really name one haha.

The events between showdowns are bland and obviously random, but that is permissible since the atmosphere is supposed to be chaotic and grim. However, the combat, the heart of its gameplay, is terrible. It has the complexity and dynamism of rolling to hit in D and D! Terrible luck mitigation for how much time you spend tweaking your item tableau and shopping, which is arguably the brunt of one’s efforts honestly. You know a game’s combat is bad when you can lock in a perfect configuration of weapons and tactics, only to get your head lopped off with a roll out of nowhere. As for ratio of originality in mechanics and interactive plot points to the price, it’s laughable.

Many better games to buy with this crazy amount of money. If you wants a tactical RPG board game experience, Descent / Imperial Assault is mechanically loads more satisfyingly.

Edit: to be clear, the bizarre, profane monster models are tremendous and unique, but the callipygian "pinup" models with their ludicrously pendulous breasts are just embarrassing. Let's not perpetuate the stereotype that board gamers are all 40-year-old basement-dwelling virgins...

There is a phrase in role playing gaming that sums up this game perfectly: "rocks fall, everyone dies". This refers to situations where there is no choice or action, merely everyone being killed off due to either luck or an angry DM. Most games try to limit this, but this game makes it the main element. Roll a dice, and there is a 75% chance one or more characters will die.

The components, text, and setting of this game are extremely high quality. The creators did a tremendous job polishing the game, and the depth of the setting shines through.

What they did not do was provide any kind of balance, any meaningful choices, or any way to mitigate bad luck. Crafting and experience both require your characters surviving. They won't.

I played a game of this, and our group did four hunts. In three of those, all party members died. In the only hunt we won, only one party member survived. All hunts were against the easiest monster. Even with observing its tactics, our group still was unable to beat it more than once out of four hunts.

The encounters are randomly chosen, and have beautiful flavor text that really draws out the setting, but the result of the vast majority of these encounters is one or more characters is killed, with no chance to change the outcome and zero player input. For example: one event happened where a roll of the dice decided that one of my characters and one of another player's characters killed each other. No choices, no input, no meaningful interaction, it was simply: someone rolled a 63, two characters died.

Most of the combats work the same way: the monster attacks, and most likely kills a character. Then characters attack, and either miss and get killed by a counter-attack, or hit, fail to wound, and get killed, or hit, wound, and then get killed. Roll poorly once? That character is dead. This game offers all the excitement of playing a group of unarmed peasants being killed by a dragon.

The odds are always stacked against anyone in the party surviving, and there is very little that anyone can do to change those odds. Your characters and your party will only last as long as everyone rolls improbably well. The only way to survive is to roll well, every time, because this game, beneath all its complex flavor, boils down to "don't roll poorly".

While I respect the amount of effort and creativity that went into this game, I would never voluntarily play it again. I enjoy games where strategy and meaningful choices exist-this game has neither. I enjoy games where what a player decides has a meaningful effect-that is totally absent in this game.

What this game does provide is endless variety in ways to die. For players that enjoy a good story, but don't like to take part, and for players who like to see their characters die over and over, this is the perfect game. For my part, I'll pass.

I rally don´t know why everybody here is so overwhelming excited about this game and everyone shows only the first tutorial fight?
I waited years to get my copy and i was so curious about our first game!

You will understand my deep disappointment after a few explanations:

1. Ok, the artwork and miniatures are great... Thats why i didn´t only gave it 1 point of raiting!
2. Why make a dungeon crawler / horror / surrvival game and only put heroes in the core box? There are only 5 different monsters in the box and over 20 survivors... after fighting the lion the third time it´s just annoying!
3. Balancing - There is just no balancing... You can die in the tutorial and it says: "Just start again and agin"
4. Settlement - Nice idea and good made, but absolut useless to define 30 - 45 Min. to craft your charakters when there are action cards in the game that say: "Roll a d10 on a 1 your charakter is just dead!"
5. The monter fights are epic, genius...? I can´t understand this comments??? You allways place monster in the middle and survivors arround and roll dice until one fraction dies. The first 10 times it´s cool, but nothing on it is new or tactial.
6. Why make 1.000 gear cards??? You have to write down what all of your charaktes have, if you end a session and on the next you have to recreate the charakter sheets. Why not just make a list of gear, without cards, and just write the items / skills direct on the charakter sheet? - We did after third session... don´t the the cards!?
7. Like the campaign on kickstarter the only goal of the core game is for you to buy more expansions to make it better. That´s not what you have promissed us Adam!
8. Really 400 dollar??? You can buy descent second edition für 60 dollar. There are more monsters, more scenarios and better gameplay in it!

I could go on like that, but i hope you understand my frustration after playing the first sessions.

But for alle those, who don´t give anything about balancing, tactics, RPG-Elements and stuff that makes most survival games great is Kingdom Death Monster the best choice! Just let all of them die, ever and ever again.

Overcomplicated? Yes, half of its features belong in a video game or an annual tax report.
Overpriced? Hell yes.
Overrated? To a degree.

We did have our fair share of fun with it, but the constant "oops, you're maimed", "sorry, but your best gear is on fire", or "you're flat-out dead, screw you in particular" events get in the way of character attachment - the kind that automatically happens if your models have names, nicknames, partners, parents and children, specs, quirks, etc., over a two-year campaign.

And design contradictions like that are felt throughout the whole game. Sure, you can keep track of your crafting materials with cards - unless you want to fight the same monster twice, because then they run out. Sure, you can head into a new monster fight without reading up on it to avoid spoiling the mechanics and surprises - but then your characters will die and you might potentially ruin hours of progress. Sure, you can make plans for the next five hunts to get that one interesting synergy going - but they will be shattered when the first random event is revealed and your character falls into a chasm or switches places with a stone statue.

There certainly are interesting and unique boss fight ideas, but most of them are more micro-management-intense than they are actually fun to play against. That being said, the overall design of the monsters and miniatures and the world-building in general are awesome, no doubt about it, but that alone can't really carry the game. After all these nights, I feel like I would rather be buried in a Dung Beetle Knight’s tunnel system than play another two-year campaign in the foreseeable future. And still, it was an experience I don't want to miss.

Too much to be enjoyable. It hit the table once when I first got it, and now it sits mostly unplayed in a room.

For sale/trade.

So the more I play this the less I enjoy it.
It doesn't help that I roll extremely poorly when it's my turn and very high rolls when it's the monster's turn, meaning all the battles are completely one-sided.

Some people seem to have enough time to play thousands of thousands of plays of this and completely abuse the system. Myself I'm having miserable experience after miserable experience everytime this hits the table. This game does not respect your time if you do not 100% dedicate yourself to it. It's overall interesting but majorly flawed in several instances, extremely repetitive, very dependant on purchasing unreasonably priced additional content, and contains too many poorly designed cards and content that has never gotten fixed and that everyone admits to skipping.

Unplayable for me without bypassing the attack roll altogether, as apparently I can never roll above 4 when attacking.

(For context, I did nearly one full campaign, which took us around half a year. We play at 4 players.)

The combat in this game is bad. The game can randomly kill you before you even play your first turn. And even outside of that, it's dull and repetitive.

It's a shame because the town progression and gear system is interesting, the worldbuilding is cool, the game is well produced... but combat take too much of the experience for me to overlook it.
painful, so much money for a complicated boss battler, much easier, more fun and cheaper games out there

The trap cards mechanic is just not fun. The game creates build potential which actively leads you into these traps, investing your very finite resources into something that actually makes the game harder and less enjoyable. The trap cards should not shuffle back in immediately, it leads to them being triggered on every players turn in some situations. Also, the RNG card draws where your people just die is not fun. While the game does have many positive attributes, it's overshadowed by these punishing and not fun mechanics. Our group got fed up after 3 sessions or so and we just quit, never to return.

really wanted to like this but turned out to be as dull as dishwater. Along slog of a set up. A weird random encounter thing followed by a random and soul crushingly difficut boss fight.
I cant really put my finger on whats wrong with it because on paper it should work. Trouble is it just doesnt. Its dull , long and no fun at all.

Im guessing like most games it has its fans who will defend it but its not for me. And lets not even talk about the price tag

Game is ruined by bad rolls, screw you on purpose mechanics, and player down time.

Boss miniatures are overpriced and most the time, stayed in the box.

The game board is essentially useless, aside for a place to count spaces and place obstacles.

Character sheets are horrible, why use paper/pencil when it changes every turn? Good luck remembering what stats change when your eraser sucks.

Glad I got to try it before ever considering it, way overpriced. $400+ is just sad. I hated it.

Rated 3/10 because boss mechanics are interesting -not fun, but interesting.
Good game, extremely hostile business practice

A giant "Boss Battler" which suffers of various flaws : miniature arrive onto sprues, if you are not into glueing and modelling this is not for you since you'll need weeks before you can even start playing. Repetitive as hell, you can feel the grind nausea after 6 or 7 missions due to facing same bosses for resources over and over again. Rougelite playstyle which for a a campaign taking up to 60-80 hours is a no go, frustration to be planned. Not real coop multiplayer, the roles in the group are so tight that personalisation is not an option you need to min max. Luck component too high.

Tried out with the TTS mod.

It's fun for a few games but the randomness of the game is not making it a nice experience.

Cardboard Reality Podcast call KDM one of the most overrated top 100 games for reasons I’m inclined to agree with:

http://cardboardreality.libsyn.com/episode-56-get-outta-here...

There’s a reason 50+ people have this for sale on the geek market. :-/

Upon reflection, this is a grind of a game. The only entertaining parts are learning the combat system, and seeing what happened to you. But the random TPKs and and imbalance combined with the length of plays and actual grinding make this a game I will not be playing again. The story is also fairly weak and leans hard on just being 'weird' rather than well written.

If this is your kind of game (lots of dice, lots of stats, tons of theme) and you ignore the problems with the math, then you'll probably love Kingdom Death: Monster.

I loathe games that I classify as Dungeon Accounting - I roll the dice, I check my stats, no wait add in this stat, and don't forget the modifier on this stat - and therefore I found this game to be a miserable experience. It reminded me of why I became a math minor instead of a math major - I got to a point where I exhausted the limits of my understanding and just couldn't fake competency any further.

In the words of Dr. Kita, who introduced me to the game: "I can say that I've done it. And depending on how much I like the person asking, I can tell them what I thought."

This game's great, if frustrating mechanics are let down by wildly inconsistent theming. One minute your fighting an enemy capable of warping time and space to age your characters out of existence, the next second it's sphincter explodes and suddenly your survivors are feasting on its droppings. That isnt an exaggeration - that literally happened when I was playing this game. Then you flip a page and you're faced with softcore rape porn. This game goes from genuinely terrifying to cringey toilet humor to misogynistic eroticism so quickly I have to imagine it was written by an angsty teenager.

Beautiful production with pretty miniatures and exciting background story distilled into tactical fighting game on oversized board. Should be played as campaign, but that appears to be super repetitive. The game tries to be something more by adding the mechanical aspect of character development from tabletop rpgs and by having players develop a settlement. The settlement is however only some cards next to the huge board and what also reminds of rpgs is the constant consulting of the game book for die rolls. The monster AI has been done pretty neatly which is great because that is what makes the game have sense.

A dice choose your adventure activity with a few game elements during the "settlement" phase. The only redeeming point of this is that I got reunited with an old friend from the university by playing this online during the quarantine

Overhyped game. If you look past the shiny miniatures and the voluptuous female protagonists it's just a dice chuck fest.
Every game you roll dice and roll dice and roll dice just to see if you survive (it has the horrible mechanic of double dice rolling, typical of all miniature wargames: roll for hit and roll for damage, so you increase dramatically your chances to fail). Very little strategy involved and not that much of a game behind it. Interesting lore, for sure, but for such a pricey game it's not worth it. Buy it only for the minis, don't expect much beyond that.
Really didn't enjoy this game
I only played a single session. But it was an incredibly lack luster combat simulator. It has tons of nice miniatures, but painting isn't my thing.
Game is overly repetitive and overpriced. Hope you like going to the rule book non stop.
Überproduzierter Ameritrash Schrott.

Overall bad game, great minis. To random and if you work on your survivor there are random encounters that “ground opens up and eats you!” I don’t mind dice in a game but this game and it’s totally unplanned randomness is a huge distraction to overall enjoyment.

Highly produced, poorly balanced. Many events are just random "Lose a character", which wouldn't be so bad if there was stronger narrative behind them and population wasn't such a limited resource. Power levels are all over the place. The entire game feels like a roguelike played in slow motion.

Yowsa. Talk about Kickstarter hype. At its core it's a mediocre skirmish game. At a non-ludicrous price point, it might be unremarkable at best. At the pricepoint it's garnishing, the game is a mindboggling example of FOMO (fear of missing out) and Kickstarter mania / hype. The out of combat settlement / campaign setting is compelling, but while it remains wrapped around such a dull skirmish game, it's not worth the dollar or time investment.
Way too random for my liking.

After hearing tons of (controversial) stuff about the game, I surprisingly had the chance to play the copy of a friend of a friend for a few "years".

So to get the theme/artwork part put of the way: I'm in general not huge on the horror theme, but afterall the general idea of fighting through and building somewhat of a society in this really horrific world actually isn't too bad and somewhat interesting and initially I even didn't mind some of the (let's call it) more "mature" parts, but after a while I personally found a lot of things to be on the "teenagers faking their IDs to pretend they are of full age" matureness level, which is unfortunate, because it pushed it over to the silly side for me.

Despite hearing a lot about theme/artwork, I didn't actually know much about the gameplay and when tought the general idea and structure of the game I was REALLY intrigued. Slowly building up a civilization with resources you get from hunts and the RPGness of the whole thing just is a great concept.
Unfortunatly in the end the gameplay had a similar impression on me as the theme: I started to be convinced by it as there are a lot of individual interesting things in there (the general idea to first hunt and then fight the monster and eventually use the resources to build up your settlement and gear, the AI cards of the monsters in the fight, the characters gaining abilities but also injuries and other flaws and probably lots of other small things i might be forgetting now) BUT eventually the game didn't really work for me when all of it came together. There was too much fiddlyness, randomness, repetition, grinding and "rock falls, you die" annoyance and too little actual choices. I actually kept thinking that the more interesting abilities and variation is on the part of the monster, so I almost got annoyed by the fact that it somewhat feels like "the game" itself is actually having more fun playing than me (which would be fine if the game would pay tons of for me to play, but if I do by a game, I kind of expect to have more fun than the cardboard).

I've noticed that since I'm playing DnD on a more regular basis, games that try to emulate an RPG without a DM in boardgame-form fall flat for me maybe more now than they did before, because it just doesn't compare to the experience and in many cases it just makes me want to play either a "pure" boardgame or a "pure" RPG but not a weird mix of both.

So maybe the best way to express my thoughts on the game are speaking of it in terms of an actual RPG. Because it feels like my problem with KD:M is that you actually get two things in that box: An RPG system and a DM running that system. And while I think that I might actually enjoy the system itself quiet a bit, the DM that comes with it is just really horrible (focusing on the wrong parts of it, dragging out the least interesting parts and having a rock randomly fall on you whenever he needs to go and get a drink - and you better drink or the "mature jokes" get old very quickly).
I like the cooperative element in the game but it is very difficult to progress and move forward.

Saw this game was in the top 100 and am on team "it's not a good game". Those of use who have played it know what it is and cheers to those who enjoy it. The ultra-horror theme is done well if you're into that kind of stuff. I have played 3 sessions of a campaign and find the gameplay and found it to be very repetitive and unrewarding. There's too many other games out there to waste my time on.

Lost my campaign with the Twilight Knight in Training variation in a couple dice rolls before I even had a chance to move my characters. Shortest campaign I've ever played. These minis need almost as much green stuff to fill in the cracks as they do patience for the tiniest pieces I've ever seen to glue in place. This has a very good civ build to it, and the short hunt stories before the boss showdown are random but interesting. At any point a character will just die in a terrible way. For masochists, what's not to like? Personally, I'd rather smear my genitalia with fish paste and dangle it in a pool of hungry piranha.

It tries to be a lot of boardgames all at once and fails to be good on most of them.
A lot of the game is just a random gamebook with random events and it gets boring quickly.
Difficulty is very artificial, the game tries so hard to be hard and forgets to be fun and challenging.
The art is awkward and the atmosphere of the game ambiguous. The game is full of drawings of half naked women (but almost no men) that feel inappropriate with the dark atmosphere of the setting. The text of some cards tries to be funny with very immature humor and makes everything worse.
A real luckfest mess. Played it eight times. Had some fun, but everytime I play I look forward to playing it less. Some cool moments sure, but ultimately not for me.

there's some stuff to like but at the end of the day, the mechanics boil down to (mostly) unmitigated dice chucking which is made worse by the fact that the odds are always slanted heavily against you.

This game is (nomen omen) real monster. With so many rules the only way to learn it smoothly is to read small portions of the rulebook and play them through immediately as proposed by the designer. Now I understand why none part of the rulebook is available to download from the internet. The rulebook is a mixture of campaign story intertwined with the rules on almost every page. So reading it before playing would have likely spoiled the fun.

It’s then the first game ever, I started playing without any knowledge about it. So first hour it was mostly reading and rare playing. The „First Story” episode went smoothly as we were being guided precisely by the rulebook. But the first regular episode „White Lion” was not that well guided. The rulebook left us in the middle of nowhere and only thanks to our mate who aleady did that part in the past we could go ahead. So the read & play concept of the rulebook is fine but it’s real shape is not as good as it should be.

The upkeep is horrible, longer than particular actions and to my taste spoils the fun. Tons of rules make this game unplayable for me. Besides after 2nd session in the campaign I see the game becomes too repetitive around the scheme: Settlement Phase, Hunt Phase and Showdown Phase. The more heros’ power, more weapons along with linear growth of monsters on the other side is something that can’t grab my attention for longer time. I had the same with „Gloomvaven Jaws of Lion”. The consecutive episodes were so repetitive that I didn’t finish the campaign being already bored enough with very predictible events. On the opposite side is „Cthulhu Death May Die” which is pure essence of the dungeon crawler combats. Fast and easy slaughter with minimum rules needed to deliver maximum fun.

This game is so amazing, the battle system is nothing special, other games make good use of the monster intelligence, and this game makes a great job in this part, but nothing that draws too much attention.

The great part of this game happens when you return home from your hunt, that is when the magic happens, events and milestones that trigger in certain circunstancies put the players into a lot of interesting and philosophical choices that I didn't see in other games.

There is a great care in a lot of details, for example if a characters is deaf he is not affected by noisy events and a lot of connections that make sense.

The environment of this game is fascinating, great job. The only downside is that this game is absolutely expensive and, for me no game is worth so much.

Kingdom Death Monster (KDM) is the originator of the Boss Battler Board game genre. The Boss Battler genre is basically Demon/Dark souls video games in board game form. Difficult and punishing. The game is broken up into 3 parts. The town phase, chase phase, and encounter phase.

The town and chase phase are great. Building your little village and gear with items you collect from defeating bosses. Chase phase is a little cat and mouse game which is just a little extra phase that adds to the hunting of the monster. The atmosphere and world that KDM provides is elite.

The problem for me with KDM is the actual boss fighting. The unique deck construction of the monster is great. Breaking body parts off the monster and affecting their future attacks is great. The issue is that the fighting is just boring. I should note I played with 4 people. Each with 1 character. I think if I had to go back the fighting portion of the game might be better if I played solo or atleast with 1 other person. It just takes too long for your turn to come around again. One can’t help feelings of boredom creep into your consciousness. Going into the game I thought it would be difficult. The game is punishing. But punishment and difficulty are not the same thing. I have nothing against the punishment of KDM. The difficulty of the monsters didn’t help alleviate any boredom. I could walk away from the table for everyone else's turn, come back and do my turn, and that's it. Not much thinking required.
The designer makes this game way worse than it could be.
Overhyped. Seems like a great oncept but way too grindy and random.

I don’t mind dice and I don’t mind randomness, but there is far too many event that can have significant influence on your settlement that it’s not actually that much fun.

It’s a bit like Dark Souls in that the ‘boss’ fights are great, but the rest of it, not so much.

Minis are good, but can look really static and awkward with the lack of pose options.

Could probably gain quite a bit from the implementation of an app to handle the settlement aspects.

Sadly, I do regret purchasing this game, as it’s just not that great.

Putting the "trash" in Ameritrash.
Literally, everything bad about American games condensed in one product.

The game can be very fun at times, but it is dramatically unfair, based on pure randomness and a hell lot of book-keeping. A total lack of player agenda. The art design is very amateurish (and tacky), and the combat (most part of the game) is actually quite bland and repetitive.

Played on TTS.
Needs house rules to make it playable, so I can't give it a great rating. With house rules it's closer to a 7.

Massively overrated game. full of gotcha moments, with little to no mitigation (i.e. oh you rolled a 10 on a random table instant death)

Base game suffers from limited hunts which get old fast.

Settlement and hunt track feel tacked on as a way to get you to the next showdown.

Art style is laughably in the vein of 14 year old trying to be edgy, i.e. look at this i put a penis and breasts on this model everyone will think i am so controversial.

TBH i don't know why i keep it, any time i feel the urge to give it another go i find myself getting board of it in earlier and earlier game sessions.

The game itself leaves a whole lot to be desired. It's just not very good but there is a reason for this if people actually decided to look into it further. The game is actually older than the 2015 date listed on BGG. It was on KS in 2012 into 2013 for funding. Most games from that time on KS were all flash and no substance. They were essentially peddling miniatures and not much more.

This is more art than it is a game. IF you are buying this for some kind of gameplay experience you are going to be disappointed.
Overly detailed and convoluted. Over-produced and a ridiculously big box. Thematically complicated but shallow and dull game play. Virtually no in-game artwork.

A luckfest with good atmosphere, great miniatures and overall good components. A lot of great details but very little strategy and tactics - many decisions are made by dice. Including instant death while performing actions, which you didn't want to perform. Not very complex, but often complicated, although in the end dice decide 80 % of the game.
Not for Me
Don't buy. Too graphic, brutal, and dark.
Satan level pledge, add ons, many promo figures from web store as well

Beautiful Artwork, great Narrative and promising ideas - Unfortunately, the idea of a "hard" game is basically to memorise AI cards and Wound card behavioral patterns of the bosses to mitigate pure randomness by d10. This is unfortunately not "hard" but just a timesink for "learning" - If a game punishes me for making mistakes or pushing my luck to far - that's one thing, but this game punishes you for not knowing stuff it hasn't showed you yet and rolling badly.
Too much book keeping

Played via Tabletop Simulator - and I'm glad I didn't spend money on this game. I really like the emerging stories that can come from the game, and the world is super interesting. I really dislike high chance of random death in almost every situation leaving me and my group feeling cheated.

Art: Pretty good; more consistency would have made this beautiful.

I rated it higher (an 8) when we first started our campaign. But I realized more and more that a) I don't like overly long campaigns and b) I am first and foremost a mechanical player. Almost everything in KD is a D10. Yes, I understand that with knowledge about the behavior pattern of the various monsters and the campaign events, you can plan what to hunt and how to equip your survivors much more effectively, thus increasing your chances. Of course, it is not all luck. And don't get me wrong, I have no problem with luck in games.

Ultimately, KD is long, repetitive and random. Points (1 - long) and (2 - repetitive) I despise, especially when they occur together. The high amount of randomness might be fitting for the world of KD and at first even lead to silly/amusing results, but at least for me, it soon breaks down into frustration.
Needed an editor to refine into something more playable.

One thing that will kill a game for me is degenerate rules. Instantly before a hunt, you can literally just get flat out killed by a d10 roll. Guess what, no one is bring someone over for a 4 hour game and saying “yah you died on one dice roll you were forced to take, sit there and drink my bear for the next two hours while we play.

So the game is a complete bullshit degenerate mess. The monster fighting is fairly weighty, burn not engaging. It feels epic and the game invites people who will get drunk and high five, so it can be a great time.

But, here’s the thing, I think most people are just happy to try a 400-$1600 dollar game at all, it’s mechanically quite sparse, the story telling is fairly interesting, the models can get super sexist and lead to it being a Game only men play, and it’s really to long and repetitive for most owners I know to have finished a campaign and really use the dozen expansions that are out.
Sadly, a very mediocre game.
The story & mythology is pretty nice, but the gameplay is trash. Clunky & unintuituve mechanics, minimal interesting decision making, repetitive play patterns, extremely unpolished feel.
World building is really cool, but the combat absolutely do not do it for me, especially in a world where Gloomhaven exists.

Nice bits (or tits) but awkward and very unwieldy. Adam probably should have employed a writer to help him develop the story.
"Never has punching the balls off a lion produced so much paperwork.."

I played this on TTS and MY GOD the randomness. The game is fine until you get to the first hunt and have to roll a d% to figure out what horrible bull crap that happens to you. Almost all of which could end up being Nothing.
Any fight that we ended up in after about the second was a cake walk. it was just the Random FUs that the game threw at you over a die roll.
This game cost to much to have the same basic game play as a random loot table from the much better RPG it could have been, but wasn't.
This is basically an overproduced D&D without the need of a Dungeon Master. It simply isn't my type of game.

I won a copy of this game through one of the BGG quiz contests. The game was on my radar already because I frequent Kickstarter and it got a lot of buzz for the amount of money this project raised. If not for winning the contest though I may have never played this game, it is not something I would even call a board game. It isn't marketed or geared towards boardgamers, which is what I am, and in that vein it is a big miss for me.

The game is prohibitively expensive for a board game. For miniature gamers perhaps this is not the case but this game tries to merge those two worlds and at least from a boardgamers perspective I have very little interest in the building and painting of admittedly EXTREMELY high quality miniatures, I'm interested in the game I get to play with them and there are very few games I want to spend that exorbitant an amount of money on.

But I won the game so the amount of money I spent for it is 0 so why the complaint...For me it is lack of content. The gameplay isn't bad, it is almost RPG combat where you roll dice to overcome defensive values and the AI deck that controls the enemies is nice. The settlement phase is a neat addition and I like the idea of harvesting enemies for the materials to make new equipment. But you don't get many scenarios to play or enemies to fight in this basic game box. For the price most people have to pay you have to really REALLY be in love with the miniatures for that. And I'm not going to pay the cost of the expansion content when I'm not that interested in the miniatures to play more. This reminds me so much of Myth, another Kickstarter juggernaut, that seemed to be selling their miniatures with a poorly planned game behind it.

As for the game component quality. While the art and the miniature are very high quality they are very off-putting. I don't mind the nudity and sexual content, I like being titillated, I bought a terrible game called Lap Dance after all. It's the more gruesome elements that have me not wanting to look at it...which is the antithesis of your goal when your artwork or miniature quality is this beautiful. I'm baffled that they included such high quality miniatures and then such poor quality cardboard tokens in the box. If you are going to have this kind of quality and price tag for a game those tokens should be made of a material besides cardboard.

I just think this game misses the mark among a board game crowd. I wouldn't buy this game most of the time or have a reason to write these comments. But I did have a copy and tried it and those are my opinions based on my perspective as a gamer. You need to keep me interested in a game in ways besides gluing and painting plastic.

I just can't get over the fiddly nature of this game, totally wrecks any sort of flow this game might have. Checking the rule book every few minutes, changing boards, writing down info, erasing info, just too much "work". When I play a game I like to have fun, make fun decisions and get immersed in the gameplay. This game almost does that but ultimately falls short. If there weren't so many ambiguities with the rules I might have been able to get past this. What a bummer, $680 Canadian and now I have the most massive box on my shelf that I will likely never play again. I would stay away from this game and play the 100's of other games out there that are much much better!

I was really excited about this game with the beautiful artwork and the amazing concept that it appeared to be... until I saw the cost. I missed the Black Friday sale, and even at $200, that is a steep entry level. This is like a GamesWorkshop-esque investment (Warhammer and 40k). There are a LOT of great games out there that don't cost $1,000 to get into. It is too bad, because I really would have enjoyed giving the game a try. If the new trend in game design is income level elitism, I'm out. I'll wait and see if it ever goes broader than the few that can afford it. If not, plenty of other games to play.

Amazing world-building.
Very very dark setting.

Gameplay and campaign-wise though, other games do it better. The combats are quite grindy too and you might still end up without that one piece you need to craft something with.
Game is a potential 10. Way the game has been supported / 1.5 kickstarter handled a definite 1.

An adult-themed pen and paper in a box with emergent gameplay. Genre defining, but aged poorly.

Has the potential to be a 10, but all the goodness is undermined by poor rulebook layout, fiddly-ness, and the severe consequences of the randomness. A single 1d10 or 2 can have game ending consequences 10-20 hours in, making this game very grindy. In addition, there is almost no dice mitigation, so roll good, metagame/cheat, or die. You can alleviate grind by spending $100-1000s on expansions, but you could also just buy better games.

The developer evergreens the game with update packs you need to better/fix the game. However, the only upgrade pack available is 1.5->1.6. As an owner of 1.0, I am hosed. This feels like Star Citizen's financial startegy in board game form.

Conceptually an interesting game. Start with pretty much nothing and build your colony of survivors. Over time go out and defeat more monsters to improve your civilization. The combat is a big part of the game and unfortunately just wasn't very interesting. Where it loses me though is the theme. It's just unnecessarily graphic and comes off as immature or comical, taking away from the immersion. And cutting minis off sprues and assembling them? Forget about it.

so weak in narrative very disappoint , the game more very expensive than other board game and give a kid story book in the box. why?

but battle is very fun i go to check 5

Festival of randomness. White Lion killed us all and this was quite interesting. During the second run one of advetureurs threw a rock. Critical hit and HL card says to roll 1d10. With the result of 10 the lion died instantly. That's it? Seriously?

One play only, felt pretty repetitive, and as many have pointed out, unforgivingly random. Interested to see if the settlement phase does anything for it, or if the game gets more strategic with later plays.
Gloomhaven + D&D + a lot of the randomness of a "you are the hero" book
2 showdowns solo on TTS. Imho, too much boring rolls, too expendables characters. May be, IRL in good company is better experience, this is why not 4-5.

Game is ok. Slow progression is not everyone's cup of tea. If you include a few expansions the game becomes better but also even more expensive. The base game is way too grindy for my taste. And after killing the white lion the 10th time, you just put everything away and say goodbye.
Bloated production. Nice components. Overly expensive. Subpar and repetitive gameplay. town building aspects are nice but hunts get old fast.

Dark and brutal game, but very intricately done, almost too much so. It's true when people say that the learning curve is steep, that you shouldn't get attached to your characters, and that you are bound to forget rules while playing. After about 15 hours of this, I needed to pack it away for a bit and play something lighter. It's psychologically challenging.

Love it or hate it. If this is a game for you, then you need a lot of time to spend on it to get the full effect. Sadly, if you put all the time and money in it and it turns out you don't like it, then that sucks. So, while it's a top game for me, I would never tell someone to buy it. Do research, then forget about it, then research it again, then if you still think it's for you, then buy it.

This is one of the most overrated games on Board Game Geek. People think because that awesome miniatures makes a game good. Sorry, but good mechanics, fluidity and fun makes a game good. KDM lacks fluidity and has a few major flaws in game design.

Even though the game seems to be an arena-like one, it is still interesting and worth trying... although, the price it will be at will be ridiculously high due to the great amount of miniatures unfortunately. 

Gave it an 7 due to its replayability (especially if you add many different monsters and expansions in the main box) but less than a 10 due to the fact that it's a repetitive arena-like game.

Also, I removed a 0.5 because there are a few features that can be replaced with cards like the tables mentioned in the videos.

EDIT : The worse part of this game is all the keywords that you need to refer to the manual to know what they are (abilities). The game designer should have written all the small rules and the abilities/drawbacks on the cards themselves so that you do not need to refer to the manual all the time (because there are plenty of those throughout the game)

Too many tables to roll on. I have no idea why you do not have 100 event cards instead of table (same goes for all other tables). Rolling on tables is archaic and stalls gameplay, which is a big no-no in game design.

Reduced it to 7 because it it costs wayyy too much for the fun it gives not to mention all the mistakes in game design as I have mentioned.

A PC version (30$-40$) with miniature packs / extension that can be bought (5$-10$) on steam would be nice. It would eliminate a lot of dice rolls and table consultation.

I do not recommend buying this until the tables are eliminated and key-words are explained on the cards themselves, but it is worth trying. It is highly overrated. You buy this game for the miniatures, not the game itself (way overpriced and overhyped, pretty ordinary game mechanics).
Rating based on the introductory hunt only. Didn't feel all that engaging, but I need to give it an honest go by playing a short campaign.

The game itself was interesting and amazing. The miniatures detailed and a joy to put together. Setup was a pain, and the hidden knowledge of building a settlement both great and painful. In the end this game required investment, and it might have gotten it if the entire wrapping story and art didn't feel like a high school artist trying to be edgy for the sake of edgy. Random gore, nudity - it was there just for the sake of it, and didn't add to anything. In the end, it was so distracting I didn't want to play it. Any game that you want to share, but are almost too embarrassed to show off simply won't last. Sold it two months after acquisition.

After trying out the first scenario and learning more about the game, I don't think I'll be committing to a campaign anytime soon. While I'm interested in seeing where the story is going, I'm not sold on the gameplay. An awful lot of dice rolling and paperwork. Also, a 36 game campaign is just too long for me at the moment.

This plays like an old-style D&D wilderness campaign with some settlement-improving thrown in. With no DM there is unfortunately no way of hiding the randomness. I didn't see how you could play "well" versus "poorly" in the battles - you either got lucky or you didn't. Real choices (ie game-changing choices) were largely restricted to what to do when back at base. But even there the outcomes of some choices were dependent on die rolls. Puzzling.

I have to scratch my head at the limit of 4 "survivors" per battle. If you've built a robust settlement with a big population why not send 5? Or 6? or 10? Seriously, why would you send 4 at a time to their deaths when 8 together would win?

I like the game in theory, but too much random roll-or-die or needed a 10 followed by a 10 to unlock some events just kills it. A lot of tonal whiplash: you get serious events happening followed by "you eat poop and everyone calls you poopy the poop eater".
Just not my cuppa tea

Because death was so common, there was ultimately no horror at all in the game, just a shrug and moving on to the next bit.
Great downtime/settlement building sections spoilt by tedious combat.

Initial Rating: 6.0 (November 2017)

I finally played the fabled Kingdom Death monster. I initially pledged for it on KS, but later, I retired my pledge as I learned a little about the game and I´m very glad I didn’t support it. KDM is not a game I want to own or play.

The rules of the game are less complex that I was expecting, however, there are many rules so teaching the game takes at least 30 minutes. Playtime is very variable and it depends on the scenario.

Love the theme.

The game´s components are AMAZINGLY good. The miniatures are incredible detailed, I love the art and in general, it has great production values. The game box is very big and heavy and the game is very expensive, but also overproduced and ambitious. It is gorgeous.

To me, KDM has a medium weight, I was expecting something much more difficult to play. The decisions needed to play the game aren’t very complex. I concede I have only played the prologue and it was hard to beat, but we didn’t have any issues with the decision making process, it is hard to pass due to luck considerations (you roll for everything). After you pass the scenario, there is another phase (I don’t know its name) but that phase is much more interesting to me. In that new phase new people are born, you distribute your loot, build equipment and buildings and you choose philosophies. In our game we became cannibals and we ate a fallen comrade, he was genuinely distressed about this, it was fun .

Another good thing about KDM is that you don’t own your character (besides killing you character seems pretty easy in the game). You can begin another scenario with a new character or you can use one created by a friend. This makes much more easy to play the game often. On the other hand, many players (scudding me) create a bond with their characters, and in KDM characters can and will die easily.

KDM is an Ameritrasher dream game, but I have been drifting away from this kind of game. My tastes have become much more Euro these past couple of years. Still, I could have bought the game if it wasn’t for the unassembled miniatures. This is THE deal breaker for me. I never buy games in which I have to assemble the miniatures and when I do (by mistake) I have sold them unplayed. I hate this activity and I won’t ever do it.

When we were playing the game, a friend said he really enjoyed the game, but he said that if he is going to play a game like this, RPGs do a much better job. I can understand his point of view but I don’t share it completely.

The luck factor seems very high, which isn’t bad in this kind of game (Cooperative Ameritrash).

I have an inkling of desire to play the camping but I won’t do it. I think the game is very repetitive so I’m not sure how much game is really here, my gut says the game hasn’t the legs for me so I think it would bore me fairly quickly. I think the big appeal comes from the miniatures but they don’t work for me.

Best with 4 players.

Bottom line, I recognize that Kingdom Death: Monster can be a great game for many players, but it isn’t for me. I have a low desire to play the campaign so I don’t think I ever will. There are many other games that really excite me and KDM doesn’t. I would have enjoyed a game like this when I was a teenager, or maybe when I first began playing boardgames (2010), but now I have moved far away from this genre, I feel the game is very repetitive and what I enjoy the most is the phase after the fight, not the fight itself. KDM comes with unassembled miniatures which is a no go for me, there is no way I’m going to glue them together. KDM isn’t as complex as I was expecting. There is also the consideration of the price, I feel there is a bias here toward liking the game just to justify the high price, this behavior isn’t that uncommon with KS games. I prefer Myth over KDM, but I already sold Myth. KDM has a very high luck factor.

Jgoyes´ Awards:
Too much dice-depending, therefore not my game, but I understand the high ratings. The game looks awesome!

There are quite a few cool systems in place in this game but I have two major issues with it.

First, spending multiple hours developing a character feels great! Climbing out of the dirt, dusting yourself off, and putting in the effort so that you finally begin to feel effective and cool in combat is awesome. Overcome the odds, become a hero, and feel badass, right!? It would be if it wasn't based on blind luck in the form of dice rolls. Then, once you manage to get lucky and start feeling that sense of accomplishment and satisfaction the game rips it away from you. Building up a character only to have him instantly killed by a settlement event against which I had no recourse is one of the most frustrating and unfun things to ever happen to me in a board game. I choose the phrasing "happen to me" in my previous sentence very deliberately. The player doesn't make things happen in KD:M, things happen TO the player.

I understand that the characters are not the central focus of the game, the settlement and the narrative is. If my character had died in combat after bad rolls or poor decision making then I could shrug and move on, try and do better next time. Feeling as though I didn't even participate in my character's death is difficult to overlook, especially when 75% of the game is spent micromanaging your character in combat. You even get a bonus at the start of the game for naming them! They should matter more than they do. Maybe this part of my response to the game can be boiled down to "the game is not for me" or "I, personally, don't have fun with this game" but that's the point of a review.

Second, the whole experience feels more like I'm reading a disjointed novel in the form of cards and narrative blocks from the rule book than I am playing a game. There isn't any player agency outside occasionally choosing one of two options in a narrative which is, ultimately, decided by the group. As an individual, there are no meaningful, tactical choices. I feel like a kid reading Goosebumps again. In fact, that's the best way I can think of to describe this game. You are presented with limited options and told to read what happens. Then, occasionally, you die without any opportunity to respond. Who am I kidding? You have more agency with Goosebumps. At least you choose the path that kills you.

It's a game that asks the player to hop in a cable car and enjoy some gorgeous scenery. Except the entire ride an angry drug addict is repeatedly punching you in the kidneys. Playing through the first time I felt like I'd enjoy it more once I knew what I was doing. Playing it again I felt like I should have enjoyed it more the first time, when it wasn't repetitive. Ultimately, while KD:M has clever moments, I find it to be an overengineered exercise in excess and hedonism that, problematically, relies on arbitrary randomness to create drama rather than offering the player interesting decisions.

Not enough tactical depth during battle for my tastes, most of the battle is just repeatedly rolling dice, at least for the core game monsters I went against. Positioning is pretty straightforward most of the times, once you know the monster's attacks you stand away from the areas that the most dangerous attacks hit i.e. don't stand in front of the lion or antelope, don't stand in the perfect thrust positions of the kingsman.

Favorite part is the gear grid system, where matching colored edges on the gear grid gives you bonuses. Would love to see more games use this system.

Overall interesting concept, creates some nice stories, but too much bookkeeping and effort to play for how much comes out of it, and battles take pretty long with low amount of decision-making.

This game is impressively well produced, but it is extremely random and brutal. For a long time I also hated it for trying to be edgy by being one of the first Kickstarters to feature nudity in a board game, especially in some of the addons and such, but while it bothers me less now as we are far past its launch, this is still not a game I am rushing to play.

Still, this game is well designed and well produced for those who want a brutal and long experience and some gorgeous production, artwork, and minis.

I used to own everything from season 1 and 2, but I only played about 70% of the core box before I got tired of its flaws.

This game started as a 9/10 for me the first 2-3 fights, then it went downhill from there as the game just threw all kinds of negative effects on you until you just dies before even reaching a fight because of hunt cards and settlement events.

The rulebook is great and also has an awesome tutorial that eases you into the game.

I love the monster reaction cards and that damage to the monster removes reaction cards to symbolize the monster being more tired/broken, which is a mechanic I find to be a simple and great solution.

Some of my problems with the game is the huge swingyness and randomness with very few ways to mitigate it.
You do have "survival points" that allow rerolls and you do have some gear items that lets you look at and rearrange monster AI cards to kinda predict what it will do, but at the end of the day, it all depends on being somewhat lucky with the D10 die rolls, but this is not much different from other games.

The worst problem is the hunt phase where you often draw cards that is very crippling for your group right before you enter a fight where you don't really have a chance unless you start at peak performance.
After having drawn a bunch of hunt cards and settlement events you'll grow tired of never having a fun boss fight as one of the players often starts with a huge negative effect making the boss fight kinda boring for that person.

This is a 1-2 player game IMO as that will let the players often have at least 1 survivor that "works".

I dont like that you need to mine/gather materials during the boss fight. Why cant the items that are left on the board at the end of the fight be auto-gathererd/mined unless they gets destroyed by the fight itself?

I prefer this over Aeon Trespass when it comes to the total package as I love the settlement phase where you build buildings and craft items.
The emergent storytelling is also fantastic.

But at the end of the day, this is a boss fighter, and it gets boring for me when all a fighter can do is move + swing weapon unless they have a headband that lets you peak on the next AI cards or dodge.
I'm more into the Middara , Gloomhaven and Street Masters camp where every character has a bunch of different cool abilities/skills they can use every turn.

So I sold it.

I've heard great things about this new hamburger restaurant in town. Not a lot of people have gone to it yet, since it's very expensive and hard to get a seat, but everyone who has gone says it's unusually good.

The big day arrives and I finally get a place in line to order. When I place my order for a hamburger and fries, the employee informs me I can't technically order a hamburger and fries, however, if the person next in line is willing to order a double order, I could have half of his order and I would just pay him part of the money. Seems a bit odd to me, but whatever, I'm willing to experience it the way it was intended. However, at this point, another employee emerges and starts arguing with the first one, explaining that yes, since this is a Friday, I am allowed to order a hamburger and fries but only if I use the special Deluxe menu that was located in a different room. I ask the staff why they didn't just put the two menus in the same room and I'm met with quizzical looks and insistence that it's because this is a "boutique" restaurant. I also ask why they don't just have a menu on their website - like every other restaurant in existence - and they tell me there would be too many "spoilers."

Eventually, my order is placed. The staff appears to be taking a very long time to get everything ready, but the food does arrive. And indeed, everything looks stunning. I dive in and start eating. For the most part it seems to be a typical hamburger and fries, but the fries are much too big to fit in their container and tend to spill out all over the table. The hamburger also comes with five parts to its bun, instead of the usual two. There's some meat in there that's actually very tasty, but it's hard to get to because of the massive (albeit, impressive) bun. In particular, there's one bite of the hamburger that tastes remarkably, impressively good. I believe it's that part of the burger where the special sauce and pickle intersected in just the right way. Unfortunately, that moment passes quickly, and I continue on with the rest of the meal. I'm eating and eating, but the fries are just so huge I finally get tired of eating them and give up. Curiously, even though I've apparently eaten a lot, it doesn't feel like I'm getting very full and start to wonder if I missed some of the food inside the elaborate containers. But before I can resolve this latest mystery, a large, bizarrely-dressed man rushes out of the back of the restaurant and storms over to my table. Without saying a word, he grabs the table, violently upending it and scattering food and packaging everywhere. I conclude that the meal is now over.

Finally I'm ready to go and need to clear my tray and garbage. I head over to the garbage can, which is absolutely overflowing with trash. I ask the staff why they don't empty their garbage. They tell me they can't empty it today because it is indeed a Friday and the garbage is emptied twice on a Monday, but not at all on any other day of the week. However, they helpfully suggest I cram all the garbage into my pockets and carry it home with me, because that's what most of their customers do.

I leave the restaurant, intrigued, but confused. I take one final look back over my shoulder, admiring the glistening facade and gorgeous signage suggesting wonders within. I head back to my car, but remember I had to park it two lots over because the lot at the restaurant only had enough space for 3.5 cars. I often think about returning in the future, but decide I'd probably be better off just going somewhere that feels less like work.

And that's what playing Kingdom Death: Monster feels like to me.

Basically it's a game of survival of a few survivors against monsters. well the monsters are at the same time antagonists and resources, cause you farm monster to build up your settlement and make better weapons and armos.

the game go in turns:
1 develop settlement (survivors are born, make weapons and armos from dead monsters, build settlement locations, play random events).
2 hunt a monster. there is some casual card and dice rolling see what happen when you hunt.

and it mix flavor from RPG, a strong background, and a story to follow.
