There are games that are more an experience than usual, and this doesn't make them good, but sure turn them into memorable. I will mention two: Legend of Zagor and Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective. The first isn't a good game - it has surpassed mechanics, great reliance on luck; still, when playing, one can have a great time with the computadorized voice, the result of encounters, etc. Many amerigames have strong thematic elements that go beyond the mechanics. Sherlock Holmes, on the other hand, creates a proper narrative not often found on board games - my favorite games, such as Arkham Horror and Sentinels of the Multiverse, aren't a good fit to deliver, after a game, a nice and coherent story. Sherlock do and you get to be part of it, to uncover the pieces and try to fulfill the puzzle.

Kingdom Death: Monster is one of those experience first games. Its base mechanics are rather simple: lots of random encounters, battles using several modifiers and possibilites that ultimely are decided by the whim of dice - in spite of having a neat IA, and learning couting for a good deal in how to handle enemies -, collecting stuff to turn into other stuff, do some work in your settlement, including some neat intimacy, and things like this. Simply put: the mechanics in Kingdom Death: Monster aren't all that great - it has bits and pieces of inspiration, but, overall, it just felt lackluster.

Nonetheless, the story isn't. Its not frequent that you see many of the situations that happen in the Kingdom Death: Monster plays. Isn't usal to battle a little and rip its leg off. Or to use its bones to make weapons and skin to turn into armor. Or to have your settlement to deal with the dead. The people start as nameless, and as more time passes, they get names, understanting, traits, form couples, and more. Suddenly you realise you're not just delevoping stats in sheet, but a way of behavior, of thinking - you get to make a micro-society.

Kingdom Death: Monster have very good components (though I dread assembling miniatures), but what makes it shine is how memorable, weird and off the beaten path many of the design choices made lead to.

Even for games I rather enjoy, but have emphasis on mechanics and results, it is hard to separate one play from another over time. I do no expect the same from Kingdom Death: Monster. In the end, what I want more is to make a mark, to create memories and special moments, not simply win or lose.

The game is entertaining, I will give it that. Starting from nothing, fighting with only a shard of stone, and building up a small (albeit dysfunctional) civilization give a great sense of accomplishment.

Sadly, that's where my major gripes start. Pretty much everything in this game can be destroyed instantly at no more than a single bad roll of the dice. I could go into details, but I guess I'll leave this spoiler free. Just don't get attached to anything: upgraded characters, cool new crafted weapons, hard fought for legendary weapons, built-up stockpiles in the settlement, the list goes on and on. Being able to lose any and all of that stuff at the drop of a hat is brutal in a way that makes this game really border on un-fun. Yes, its a fresh and new feel for a game, yes, its funny at times, but its also really disheartening and at times very annoying.

But lets ignore that for a second and move onto combat. What will you do on your turn, well, you'll either attack or you wont, and most of the time that's based more on whether you are lucky enough to still be in range after the enemy has its way with things since your last turn. There just aren't many meaningful decisions. Maybe you want one character to go first to hopefully apply some weakness on the enemy that the others can exploit, but that's about it. Generally you have one weapon and no special abilities, so if your in range you attack, if you aren't, you probably move closer.

Overall, it just seemed like the game was playing me more than I was playing it. If you're into having an extremely brutal experience and some funny and pretty good storytelling, this game can be alright. If you want to have meaningful tactics and strategy in your dungeon crawler, there are better options.

(Side note: the artwork in this game, while done rather well, is regularly NSFW for no important reason. Not the kind of thing you want to play with the family. Not that my wife and kids are into this heavy of a game anyways... but just sayin'.)

After reading the rules, I thought I would really like this game's showdown's, but wouldn't like the settlement phase. Instead, so far after playing the first two lantern years, the opposite has been true.

I had heard really good things about the monster AIs. However, so far fighting only the white lion, too many of them seem like just variations of move and attack. The slight variations adds upkeep of figuring out what the lion will do each turn, yet isn't enough to develop a feeling of variety. I also don't like how since you start with very few weapons against only one enemy, which so far makes there be very little variety in your turn to turn decisions.
This being early in the game and only the first enemy, these aspects may well change in the future. I know at least the game is trying to give a lot of different ways for you to use your survival points, although I'm not sure that is the way I wanted the variety to come from.
What I disliked the most about the showdowns though is how often hitting the monster can backfire. In moderation, this mechanic makes thematic sense in terms of simulating inflicting enough pain to anger the monster but not actually seriously wounding it. However, this mechanic is instead fairly common on at least the lion's hit deck. The lion was doing more damage on the survivors' turns than its actual turns, which feels really counterintuitive (although this is partially because we could not plan around the hit deck effects).
I also dislike that the monster's AI starts off very varied but gets less so as the game progresses, until it becomes one-dimensional at the end. It makes the fights sort of fizzle out at the end.


As for the settlement phase, I thought I would really dislike having to restart your characters, as doing so would kill off a sense of progression and growth you normally feel in games with fantasy dungeon fights. However, you still end up getting that same sense of progression and growth through the growth of the settlement instead, and while I would generally prefer the "part of something larger" feel of the settlement growth versus the more personal growth of an individual character, a settlement focus feels novel compared to the personal growth of other fantasy campaign games. While keeping track of everything in this phase is fiddly, it feels like the decisions here may make a bigger impact than the actual showdowns.

The story's plot isn't amazing, but the universe is unique for the board game world, and the phrasing of the story is better than most story-driven games I've played.

I'm glad to see the art isn't as risque as the Kickstarter page made it seem to be. While there is a lot of grotesque and naked imagery in the story events, it is more lack of clothing due to being a stone age-level civilization in a bleak and barren land, rather than lack of clothing for the sake of being sexy.

EDIT: As you get stronger, the monster failure effects aren't as prevalent. However, fighting the same monster multiple times even with different AI cards feels repetitive. Also, while fights can play out differently every time, since this wasn't caused by your strategic decisions, nor was it built up by the narrative, this can make things feel out of the blue rather than a sense of wonder and realism that anything can happen. In one battle, the monster got a bleeding effect that caused them to take damage every time they moved. While we had purposefully thrown multiple founding stones at the start of the combat to get crit bonus effects, the effect that we ended up getting felt like a random pull from the hat rather than the fruition of our efforts. That fight ended with us just scattering and letting the monster chase us around until it finished itself off.

The mechanically from what I can tell the game is composed of layers of puzzles on top of puzzles. Risk-taking is built into every crevice of the game.

KDM has some cool features: the models, the artwork, the snippets of story and flavour you get. During the first few sessions, the flavour is great, and you get excited making characters, founding your town and seeing what happens. After a while, however, this starts to fade, leaving the core mechanics to hold the game together.

These core mechanics consist of about a half-hour of arranging equipment (this becomes more of a problem with a variable group, or with lots of character death), about a half-hour of rolling dice during the hunt (hoping you reach the fight without dying or being seriously disabled), about an hour of fighting (which is pretty good as a strategy exercise, but again random wounds can be instantly lethal), and then about an hour of figuring out what to do with your resources (after seeing who randomly dies when you get home).

KDM is often praised for its brutality, but this is where the game falls apart for me. While I really appreciate the value of risk and major consequences, it needs to be meaningful to work. Unfortunately, KDM substitutes out meaningful player decisions for random, flavourful outcomes. Too many random events are simply "roll or die", instead of "take no risk and a penalty, or a great (potentially lethal) risk for a reward. Too many times does half the party die arbitrarily during the hunt before the showdown, and have to sit out for the next hour.

My main problem with the game is that it lacks agency. When my characters die, I want to know that I could have made a choice to avoid it. Instead, the game makes most of the significant decisions for you. It's satisfying when a character struggles through a difficult fight, battered, broken and bleeding, defeating the foe that slew all of their allies to protect the village. It's less satisfying when they finally reach home, victorious, and the random settlement event is "roll or die" (or even "straight-up kill your longest-surviving character, then roll or die for another").

The game does play differently solo; nobody has to sit out, and the party benefits through being able to make optimal gear decisions, rather than trying to give everyone bits and pieces fairly. The solo game is primarly one of optimising combat tactics and optimising resource usage; a bit more of a puzzle to solve. It still suffers from lack of agency, but you can handwave it more easily and ignore events.

Overall, KDM is okay, and enjoyable for a few sessions. I would enjoy it more if it was designed to threaten and pose risks, rather than kill arbitrarily. As it stands, there's a small degree of "you could have avoided this" and a huge degree of "lol you're dead".

Overrated. It's a decent boss battler, but overall the campaign is repetitive, often cruel, and frequently plays itself. Much of the events your survivors will undergo are entirely random and occur with little or no input from the players. For example, the infamous "Murder" settlement event kills your most experienced survivor and there's nothing you can do about it. Furthermore, that same event will randomly determine if another survivor (the "murderer") will also die immediately. If the murderer is not executed, they will live to kill again, meaning the Murder event will occur again during the next settlement phase. Although not all events are quite so devastating, you will frequently encounter situations where your survivors will be maimed and/or killed due to no fault of your own.

Pros:
- Most intense dice rolls I've experienced in a game because there are a lot of rolls where a lot is at stake.
- Encountering a monster knowing nothing about it and learning/being surprised by its move set is interesting. The way the cards are discarded might also mean that monsters can surprise you later by pulling out a card you never saw.
- Lots and lots of potential to explore character builds, settlement builds, etc.
- Tons of content, so you can invest tons of hours into this game if you love this style.

Cons:
- A lot is at stake on dice rolls. Some of it is too random for me (especially not being able to mitigate certain rolls)
- Once you've learned a monster, going on the same hunt becomes pretty grindy.
- The battle mechanics aren't very intuitive. Once you've played a decent number of scenarios they become engrained, but if you're in a campaign that doesn't meet super frequently there is often relearning of mechanics.
- You need to be willing to really invest time in this game to get the most from it - probably hundreds of hours. It doesn't pull me in enough for that kind of commitment (I'm guessing I've played 20-30 hours at this point?).
- You need well-organized book-keeping to run a full campaign of this. Lots to keep track of.

Kingdom Death Monster plays like a Dark Fantasy version of XCOM: Enemy Unknown.

You start with 4 survivors with very rudimentary equipment and abilities and are thrown into a fight against a White Lion monster, where the monsters actions and attacks are determined by a decision tree on A.I. cards you have to draw.
After defeating it, you loot its body for resources and return to your homebase, were you decide how to use the resources and battle experience to upgrade your settlements facilities, population and technologies development. You also build new equipment and manage your survivors' progresses, all the while a background event is happening, that can support or hamper your base camp operations.

After that, you send out a team of 4-6 Survivors on a hunt, which plays a bit like these "Choose your own Adventure" books from Steve Jackson, where random events happen to your Protagonists, again buffing, damaging or killing them on the way to their hunts prey. All depending on your prior choices for character development and - of course - dice rolls.

Once you reach your target, it's a battle again.

This circle repeats itself, until you have defeated the final boss monster - the Gold Smoke Knight - or your settlement has died out.

In the former event you'll have spend about 50+ hrs playing that one single "People of the Lantern"-campaign. And contrary to Legacy games, you can actually play it again no problem.

Kingdom Death: Monster might feel a bit cumbersome and uneven sometimes (there are some actual Roleplaying parts (!) forced in there now and then - which might irritate pure boardgamers - but overall, as a sum of its elements, it is a very entertaining and immersive experience.

While you can play it in Solo-mode, it is much better enjoyed (or endured) with friends accompanying you during the campaign, sharing all the ups and downs of it.

The miniatures of the Core Set are beautifully sculpted, once assembled.

Yet, assembly demands some experience in the use of hobby knife, files (sanding), model building plastic glue and Green Stuff/Liquid Green Stuff usage.

Hobbyists coming from the Tabletop Wargaming angle will tackle the hurdle no problem; amateurs, though, might feel it to be an overwhelming or sobering challenge to assemble the models, especially since some of them have a multitude of parts, which (depending on the model built) sometimes don't fit properly into each other or leave quite some noticeable and hence annoying gaps.
Here you should take your time slowly, because once assembled and treated well, they are awe-inspiring sculpts to behold, well worth the price. True pieces of art, well like the rest of the core boxes content.

You can see, and feel all the creative love and energy that has been put into it in every corner of its design.

The game goes heavy on the time it demands from you:

Be it assembling the models, painting them, or playing the game, it will ask for your full devotion, care and karma to maintain it right.

But if you are willing to give in to its demands, you will most definitely get back the money and time you have spent into it.

This really is something unique. I think I did a pretty good job at not letting all of the hype put me in a state of seeing Kingdom Death through an overly optimistic eye during the wait before receiving my copy of the core game -although, I probably never would have gone for it in the first place due to it's price point if it weren't for all of the buzz and the overall features being promised in the game. During that period, I even purposefully avoided looking into the rules very much so that it would be a fresh experience, and something that I'd get to discover in person and with my own reason. And I've got to say, WOW, this really is something unique!

The Models:
+Made of excellent material and with an excellent process, as far as I can tell.
+The fixed pose figures (the monsters, starting survivors, intimacy survivors, and young and old survivors) have excellent sculpts.
+Assembling the models wasn't something I was looking forward to, honestly, but after I got into it, I just kept going! For like two days!
-Are what make Kingdom Death so expensive. Like I said, I've enjoyed putting them together, to my surprise, but I personally would like the gameplay and experience just as much even if the figures were replaced with nicely illustrated tokens. Assembling (and painting, if you like) the figures kind of seems like it's own thing in itself - like a second hobby project that happens to come in the same box as a board game. If you've already tried it and know you don't enjoy assembling models, then sadly, I would have a hard time recommending this package to you. About 70% of what you are paying for is the plastic... Unless you know somebody that does enjoy putting together miniatures, whose skills you trust, and is willing to do it, then I'd say go for it! If you've never tried it for yourself before, and you have some spare time, then I'd also recommend giving it a shot. All you need is super glue, sprue cutters, an X-acto knife, and tweezers occasionally. Other things that will really help are patience, good closeup eyesight (or a magnifying glass), and dexterous fingers.

(I've got a lot more to say about Kingdom Death, but not the time to do it at the present.)

Wonderfully gritty horror themed fantasy RPG in a box. The hunt, showdown, and settlement phases are all exciting and immersive. Building new weapons, armor and tools out of the remains of your prey is particularly memorable. Really enjoyed our campaign, but while I wondered if the game will feel too "samey" fighting against the same old monsters the real danger was in the random events during the settlement phase. Our settlement was essentially wiped out within two lantern years. Also, would have liked to see the overarching storyline be more front and center in the early stages of the game. There are also some infamously crazy die rolls, but it's a genuine part of the experience.
A true masterpiece for every ameritrash fan.

Kingdom Death: Monster is a relentless cooperative, skirmish game with a campaign and settlement building game.

Pros:
+ Artwork: weird at times but quite unique. Clearly formatted cards.
+ Atmosphere: world of survival and deposable heroes as well as the hillarious bosses.
+ Cool, detailed combat system that offers a lot of possibilities.
+ Players have to figure out what they are fighting (unknown).
+ Fun monster AI, unique for each monster.
+ Combat system: player control over the monster deck is the most fun part.
+ Fun settlement phase due to progression. However, it is also the cause for grinding resources.

Neutrals:
# Plenty of random encounters and events (with unexpected, random deaths). Some random events can be quite devastating.
# Very random / dice rolling / luck based / death (especially for the Hunt phase)
# The Hunt phase is my least favorite phase. It is all about roll to resolve with some decision-making in order to determine how weak your party starts the upcoming boss fight. It takes too much time. However, for the first time, the events are very fun (novelty effect).
# Sometimes repetitive (especially grinding resources)
# Campaign-driven
# Do not get attached to characters which will die sooner than later
# All about combat
# A lot of rule referencing
# Long, time-consuming game
# The course of the campaign is kind of a big optimization puzzle in order to win the game.
# A lot of upkeep with constantly erasing and re-writing your character sheets
# Very expensive game
# Very big game box
# Too many expansions????
# Basically a solo game

Cons:
- I do not mind the randomness in this game. For me, there is just too much time-consuming grinding for resources over the course of the campaign (fighting a boss over and over again). The battles also get samey after some time because there is not much tactical choices besides positioning, attacking, and manipulating the AI deck.

Similar games:
* Aeon Trespass: Odyssey: Greek mythological setting, similar combat system, 7th Contentint inspired exploration., technology research.
* Townsfolk Tussle: one-shot, easy-going boss battler
* Kingdoms Forlorn: tweaked combat system by the same Designer of Aeon Trespass, narrative tile exploration adventure phase.
* Oathsworn: narrative campaign game with boss fights.
* Primal: The Awakening: focuses on boss fights and deck building. All about combat on an abstracted grid, no exploration phase.
This game is pure genius, but a bit put off by poor release and communication. The GC addons are, in general, very cumbersome alternatives to the base game engine - a lot of extra work.

Pros:
- What I like the most about boardgames? Thinking about a game, even when not playing it. And that´s exactly what KDM has to offer. What gear should I craft next? What would help in my next showdown against monster xy? Does a rearrangement of the gear I have, make that specific Survivor better? And so on. I love it!
- Beautiful Artwork
- with expansions you get a lot of modularity to customize your campaigns
- The Monsters are very thematic (more than in Aeon Trespass: Odyssey) and building the AI deck random every time makes them feel different, even when fighting them multiple times
- lots of options for the Survivor gear layout, experimenting with Synergies is fun
- Survivors get individual over the course of the campaign (fighting arts, disorders, Injuries, and other stats)

Neutral:
- you need a custom storage system and a table where you can leave the core components of the game. Otherwise it´s a lot to set up and teardown every time you play. Same goes for ATO.

Cons:
- I played this solo in the beginning. It is harder to play and not forget things (Disorders, Severe Injuries, Gear abilities, temporary modifiers etc.) than ATO. I can manage to play ATO Solo without any problems, but KDM is better for 2 players.

I used a few quality of life add-on´s to make it easier to handle solo. I use the wooden player dashboards from fancybutfunctional, a 3d printed Monster controller board from etsy, custom tokens from Klutz studio and the very useful Scribe for KDM app.

Don´t get me wrong, I think that KDM has the cleaner Ruleset. ATOs rules make me question and look on the Internet more than KDM. But KDM makes me forget things more and I have to be more focused during the showdown, if that makes sense.

Review: The game has an amazing ability to combine the experience of levelling up, base building with a narrative gameplay that doesn't overshadow the recurring boss fights.

It is a system that brings the gameplay of computer games like Heroes of Might and Magic to the tabletop. There is a lot of bookkeeping, which can be streamlined with use of an app, a good deal of randomness, and a very, very rich gaming experience.

Personally, I love the fact that every time a survivor has evolved and gotten new gear, I have the opportunity to model and paint a new interesting figure with a story to it.

I highly recommend it.

Kingdom Death (Backerkit)
2022-01

Production Quality  [9]
➕Great looking models
➕Artwork and direction is fantastic
◾Packaging is functional but not perfected (outside organizer is preferred)
◾Most components are solid
➖Model assembly required for play
➖Cards easily damaged outside of sleeves

Theme and Setting  [10]
➕Story is short and sweet, leaves interpretation up to the players
➕Dark and gritty atmosphere brings players into the game
◾An 18+ setting with explicit scenes

Rules and Instructions  [9.5]
➕A good tutorial to the combat basics of the game
➕Rulebook has decent structure grouped by phases to help find details more quickly
➕The rulebook contains a moderate and competent index for reference
◾Complexity of the mechanics make the rules sometimes hard to follow

Gameplay Mechanics  [10]
➕Combination of strategy, combat mechanics, and dice rolling create a well crafted boss battling game aspect
➕Victory over monsters create an exciting and choice filled advancement and structure phase
➕Plenty of options and diverse mechanics make the whole game stay exciting over various plays
➕Game is well balanced once you get the hang of the difficulty and advanced combat mechanics
◾Difficulty may be off-putting for some players
◾Game management gets tedious the fewer players you have under 4
➖Random acts may kill off characters or even the entire game and can cause a lack of enjoyment
➖Death in a combat encounter or hunt can cause a player to sit out of the game

Time and Cost  [9]
➕Just from the base game there is hundreds of hours of gameplay and much replayablity.
